To explain the three minor thirds: B-D a minor third, D-F a minor third and F-Ab another minor third. In case you have difficulty understanding why B-D-F-Ab is a diminished 7th, it is so because the structure of this chord is such that there are three minor thirds above the root B, with Ab as an interval of a diminished 7th above the root. To explain the three minor thirds: B-D a minor third, D-F a minor third and F-Ab another minor third. J McG, Technically, there is no limit with parallel sixth progression and you can go on and on and on. It is not limited to end at the ii6 chord. But of course we don't want to go on and on and on. Usually when using progressions, we want to move somewhere, going from one point to another. In Lesson 3, Prof Edwards exemplifies the use of parallel sixth progression that could be used in a phrase of a composition. In a musical phrase, we want to conclude it with a cadence, that is, a progression of two chords that give us a 'conclusive end' to the phrase (such as the V-I, called the perfect cadence). He starts off the the parallel sixth progression with the vi6 chord up until ii6, and then decides not to continue further so that he could resolve this phrase with the ii6-V-I progression. It is like you say, a combination of the parallel sixth progressions with the ii-V-I progression. Note that this is not definitive. It is not a rule to end the parallel sixth progression like this. You may, just for example, want to end with a ii6-V-vi instead (a different cadence called interrupted cadence), or combined logically with other progressions.
